cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to fundamental principles of linguistics with particular attention to sound structure and its acquisition, processing, and variation; practice in elementary analytic techniques using data from a broad spectrum of languages.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Linguistics: Sound Structure

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Prerecorded lectures will be posted on Monday and students are expected to watch them before or on Tuesday.

Office hours (“contact hours”) will be online, on Tuesday 1-2 and 6-7. Students are expected to watch the lecture before attending the office hours and before tutorials.

Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous. Students are expected to attend their assigned tutorial and have their camera switched on (with the microphone on only when they speak). No section will be recorded. A prerecorded tutorial (without students) will be posted 2 days after the tutorials; however, missing a tutorial will result in a deduction in the tutorial participation mark.

courses.name: Introduction to Linguistics: Sentence Structure and Meaning

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to fundamental principles of linguistics with particular attention to sentence and meaning structure, their acquisition, processing, and variation; practice in elementary analytic techniques using data from a broad spectrum of languages.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Linguistics: Sentence Structure and Meaning

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Prerecorded Lectures will be posted online (asynchronous). Students are expected to watch them before participating in Practice Labs, Office Hours and Tutorials. Tutorials will be offered online, at their scheduled times. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Babel: Language in the Mind of Speakers

cmCourseInfo.description: What is the relation between language and thought? In this course we examine how language is represented in our minds, and how language and cognitive processes interact. While the link between words and meanings is arbitrary and reflects culture, language is considered to be a universal property of our species. We will examine the place of language in the architecture of the mind; the debates about the universality of language structure vs. linguistic relativism; and how language and thought interact in children’s development. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Babel: Language in the Mind of Speakers

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

As this is a seminar, class will take place per the meeting schedule (i.e., synchronously), and no recordings will be available. To participate in class activities, students need the ability to use Zoom, and will be expected to participate in both written and spoken discussion (i.e., a working microphone is required, video is highly recommended). To prepare for class, students will be expected to read any assigned readings and/or watch assigned videos and/or participate in discussion on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description:
We will explore the ways in which information is communicated in conversation. We will consider systematic ways in which what a speaker intends to communicate with language goes beyond what one says in conversation. The goal of the course is to investigate the ways in which speakers rely on knowledge of language and implicit “rules” to enrich and transform the literal content of someone’s utterance.

Students will familiarize themselves with some fundamental concepts in linguistic semantics and pragmatics. They will develop analytic skills necessary to analyze a text in an academic context and beyond. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language and Communication

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use BB Collaborate, and will be expected to be able to participate orally as well as through the chat and the Quercus discussion board

cmCourseInfo.description: There are estimated to be about 7000 languages currently spoken in the world. What do they have in common? In what ways are they different? This course will explore these questions, covering such topics as meaning, sound systems, the structure of words, the order of words in sentences, question formation, concepts such as subject and object, tense systems, pronoun systems. We will also discuss language loss and revival. Students will develop analytic skills as they consult published grammars and other resources to address these issues. Students will share their findings through oral and written presentation. Examples will be drawn from a wide range of languages. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language Diversity

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously. Students will interact with the instructor synchronously (in-person or online) during in-class activities per the meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use Quercus and to stream videos using the MyMedia service (http://mymedia.library.utoronto.ca). Students who decide to participate in the in-class activities online will need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, and will be asked to interact with their classmates and with the instructor using audio and video.

cmCourseInfo.description:
We will explore how speakers use Heritage Languages in Toronto, using data recently collected in the GTA, so students should be familiar with one of these languages. We will collect, organize and interpret information about heritage languages in Toronto. We will look for speech patterns that differentiate first, second and third generation speakers in Toronto from corresponding speakers in their countries of origin, and look at the effects of cultural and language attitudes and usage.

Students will develop analytic skills as they explore a range of research methods and resources to address these issues. Students will share their findings through oral and written presentation, including online formats. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Exploring Heritage Languages

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course meets synchronously (live-streamed). Students will find all material and (links to) tools for this course in Quercus. In addition to MS Office (or equivalent), they will need to install and use the freeware: ELAN; and have a microphone and camera for their computer in order to participate in discussion.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Aug 6, 2020: Section added.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: August 6, 2020: Section added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to Language is a general-interest course on language. Possible topics include: the structure of language; how language changes over time, the social and psychological aspects of language, language and culture, the origin of language, writing systems, and language acquisition. (This course cannot be used as an entrance to programs in linguistics, and cannot be used as a prerequisite to any linguistics courses unless otherwise indicated.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Language
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: LIN100Y1, LIN101H1, LIN102H1, LIN101H5, LIN102H5, LINA01H3, LINA02H3, ANT253H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. Students are expected to watch asynchronous video lectures prior to the following tutorial. Tutorials will be delivered online synchronously at their scheduled times and will not be recorded. Students are expected to have an electronic device with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to Language is a general-interest course on language. Possible topics include: the structure of language; how language changes over time, the social and psychological aspects of language, language and culture, the origin of language, writing systems, and language acquisition. (This course cannot be used as an entrance to programs in linguistics, and cannot be used as a prerequisite to any linguistics courses unless otherwise indicated.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Language
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: LIN100Y1, LIN101H1, LIN102H1, LIN101H5, LIN102H5, LINA01H3, LINA02H3, ANT253H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online only, asynchronously, via Bb Collaborate inside the course Quercus page; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Tutorials are online and synchronous, being held live at specific times for all the students enrolled in a particular tutorial.

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of English spoken in Canada. Topics include: vocabulary items, usage surveys, non-standard dialect enclaves, regional variation and historical development. Students will develop original research projects in linguistics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian English

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online only, asynchronously, via Bb Collaborate inside the course Quercus page; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: English has a rich vocabulary. We will learn how it has developed over time, and investigate aspects of the meaning and pronunciation of words. Most of all, we will study how words are put together, so that students will be able to recognize and analyze unfamiliar words.
cmCourseInfo.title: English Words

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online only, asynchronously, via Bb Collaborate inside the course Quercus page; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Tutorials are online and synchronous, being held live at specific times for all the students enrolled in a particular tutorial.

cmCourseInfo.description: How the English language works: students analyze a wide variety of English grammatical structures and learn how they vary across dialects and change through time.
cmCourseInfo.title: English Grammar

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students will be expected to watch the asynchronous lecture videos prior to the following tutorial. Tutorials will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedule and will not be recorded. It is recommended that students have an electronic device with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Additionally, several online office hours (specific times TBD) will be available to students to drop in and ask any content and/or clarification questions.

cmCourseInfo.description: Phonetics is a linguistics course that investigates the sounds most commonly used in languages from an articulatory and acoustic point of view, with practice in their recognition and production. Students will learn the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and practice transcribing a wide variety of speech sounds.
cmCourseInfo.title: Phonetics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. Tutorials are delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students are expected to watch asynchronous video lectures prior to the following tutorial, but otherwise, learning is self-paced.

cmCourseInfo.description: The nature and organization of phonological systems, with practical work in linguistic analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sound Patterns in Language

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and also recorded (permitting asynchronous attendance, though synchronous attendance is recommended). Tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use Zoom and will be expected to be able to participate orally or through the chat.

cmCourseInfo.description: The nature and organization of syntactic systems; their relation to semantic systems and the linguistic organization of discourse; practical work in linguistic analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Syntactic Patterns in Language

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials are delivered online, per the meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to meaning within linguistics and the interpretation of language in context. Topics include logical and semantic relations, pragmatic concepts such as presupposition and implicature, the nature of thematic roles, quantifiers and scope relations, the expressions of temporal and modal relations in natural language.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Semantics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online, per the meeting schedule. Lectures and tutorials will not be recorded. Students will need internet access and the ability to use Bb collaborate and Zoom. They will also need access to a microphone and a camera in order to participate in classroom activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: How does linguistic variation construct identity? Introduction to recent sociolinguistic literature on language contact, multilingualism, code-switching, expressions of ethnic solidarity and regional identity, sex and gender differentiation, dialect geography, sociophonetics, perceptual dialectology, diffusion of norms in mobile populations, documentation of variation in lesser studied languages, and changes across the life-span.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Sociolinguistics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Students will participate in tutorials online per the meeting schedule. Students will find all material and tools for this course in Quercus. In addition to MS Office (or equivalent), they will need to install and use ELAN freeware, and have a microphone and camera for their computer. Students may occasionally be expected to watch asynchronous videos prior to class meetings.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project in linguistics. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: https://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/academics/research-opportunities

Delivery Instructions

TBD.

cmCourseInfo.description: Principles of research design, data collection, and a wide variety of statistical techniques for research in various subfields of linguistics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Quantitative Methods in Linguistics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: LIN101H1, LIN102H1 and one full course in LIN/JAL/JFL/JLP

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use Zoom and will be expected to be able to participate orally or through the chat. Students will also need access to the R programming language.

cmCourseInfo.description: This linguistics course examines cross-linguistic typological features found in the languages of the world. Special attention is given to describing morphological and syntactic patterns found cross-linguistically. The goal of the course is to draw on the diversity of languages in order to uncover language universals. (Not offered every year)
cmCourseInfo.title: Language Diversity and Language Universals

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are delivered online, per the meeting schedule. Lectures will not be recorded.

cmCourseInfo.description: Basic issues in current phonological theory. Problems focusing on analysis and theory. (Students who want to pursue graduate studies in linguistics are strongly advised to include this course in their program.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Phonological Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use BB Collaborate, and will be expected to be able to participate orally as well as through the chat and the Quercus discussion board.

cmCourseInfo.description: This linguistics course is an introduction to the acoustic phonetics of the vocal tract, including acoustic properties of speech and its analysis using instrumental techniques.
cmCourseInfo.title: Acoustic Phonetics

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). 

Readings will be assigned at the end of each class and assignments will be given out both in class and via a class email that day. 

Assignments and projects can be submitted either online or in class.

cmCourseInfo.description: A course in syntactic theory and analysis within a current formal framework. (Students who want to pursue graduate studies in linguistics are strongly advised to include this course in their program.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Syntactic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online, per the meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: This linguistics course focuses on the study of natural language semantics and the relation between interpretation and syntactic structure. Topics include predication and quantification, scope and anaphora, problems of discourse analysis, the interpretation of different types of pronouns, and ellipsis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Semantic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use BB Collaborate, and will be expected to be able to participate orally as well as through the chat and the Quercus discussion board

cmCourseInfo.description: In this sociolinguistics course, we explore linguistic variation and its social implications, especially the quantitative study of phonological and grammatical features and their correlations with age, sex, ethnicity, and other social variables.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociolinguistic Patterns in Language
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: LIN251H1, or permission of the instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online only, asynchronously, via Bb Collaborate inside the course Quercus page; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Tutorials are online and synchronous, being held live at specific times for all the students enrolled in a particular tutorial.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project in linguistics. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: https://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/academics/research-opportunities

Delivery Instructions

TBD

cmCourseInfo.description: This course uses constructed languages (e.g., Esperanto, Klingon, Dothraki) to explore crosslinguistic patterns in language structure. Topics include phonological and morphosyntactic typology, language change over time, effects of culture and environment on language, history of language construction, standards in writing descriptive grammars, and critical analysis of research on language diversity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Linguistic Typology and Constructed Languages
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 5 required 200-level courses (LIN228H1, LIN229H1, LIN232H1, LIN241H1, LIN251H1), AND LIN322H1 Phonological Theory OR LIN331H1 Syntactic Theory, or permission of the instructor.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use Zoom and will be expected to be able to participate by orally as well as through the chat.

cmCourseInfo.description: Topics may include: the phonological, morphological, syntactic, and semantic systems; the writing system; a brief diachronic sketch; linguistic variation and sociolinguistic aspects. (Not offered every year).
cmCourseInfo.title: Structure of a Specific Language
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: LIN228H1, LIN229H1, LIN232H1 + 1 FCE at THE 300+ level in LIN/JAL/JFL/JLP/JLS

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online, per the meeting schedule. It is recommended that students have access to a device with a microphone in order to participate in class activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers current research in formal semantics and pragmatics. Topics may vary from year to year. The course is intended to be a seminar-style course; it includes reading primary literature and writing a research paper.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Semantics and Pragmatics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online, per the meeting schedule.

courses.name: Language Variation and Change: Theory and Analysis

cmCourseInfo.description: The theory and practice of sociolinguistics. The inter-relationship between language and society from the perspective of collecting, organizing, and analyzing patterns in natural speech data, including field methods and quantitative methods for correlating linguistic and social variables.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language Variation and Change: Theory and Analysis

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

One lecture per week is live-streamed and recorded (synchronous attendance recommended, but asynchronous attendance possible). The other is live-stream because it’s a hands-on lab. Students will find all material and (links to) tools for this course in Quercus. In addition to MS Office (or equivalent), they will need to install and use this freeware: ELAN, Praat, R and Rbrul; and have a microphone and camera for their computer.

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of language endangerment and language revitalization efforts, focusing on Indigenous languages of Canada. Topics include language classification and a survey of major features of the languages, what it means for a language to be endangered, the factors that contribute to language shift, and efforts to reverse language shift, including discussion of literacy, documentary linguistics and dictionaries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Revitalizing Languages
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: LIN101H1, LIN102H1 plus 2 FCE at the 200+ level in LIN/JAL

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online, per the meeting schedule. Slides/handouts used in class will be available for download, but lectures will not be recorded. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Linguistic argumentation, practice in constructing and evaluating hypotheses, and critical evaluation of representative articles. Emphasis on the structure of arguments rather than on the analysis of a particular language.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Analysis and Argumentation

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. They will not be recorded. Students need internet access and the ability to use Bb collaborate and Zoom. They will also need access to a microphone and a camera in order to participate in classroom activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: A specific topic in linguistics will be explored in depth in Special Topics in Linguistics. Students will learn about a narrowly-focused area of linguistics, including guided instruction in how to undertake critical reading of primary literature, develop a research topic and write a linguistics research paper. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. (Not offered every year)
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Linguistics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.0 LIN FCE at the 200+ level, of which 1.0 LIN FCE must be at the 300+ level. Permission of the instructor will also be required.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online, per the meeting schedule. Slides/handouts used in class will be available for download, but lectures will not be recorded. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: A research or reading project in linguistics undertaken by the student under the supervision of a staff member. Open only when a faculty member is willing and available to supervise. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Individual Project
